awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Microbially-derived, Precipitated Calcium Carbonates for Industrial Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of precipitated calcium carbonates (PCCs) using microbial precipitation under ambient conditions. Particulate (micron scale) calcium carbonate has a number of industrial uses in the manufacture of paper, thermoplastics, sealants and adhesives, and paints. Currently, the production of PCCs requires sintering (heating to >1,000°C), which releases an estimated 162 kilotons of carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere annually. The anthropogenic emission of greenhouse gases represents a significant threat to our planet, with climate impacts that will disrupt societies and damage important ecosystem services. The proposed microbial processes by-passes sintering and sequesters CO2 in the production of PCCs.  This technology represents a novel target to reduce CO2 emissions, while carbon capture credits may increase profit margins in a market that is worth $5.6 billion annually. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a microbial metabolic pathway that uses cellular calcium cations (Ca2+) homeostasis to initiate the precipitation of micron-scale carbonates sourced from atmospheric CO2. By understanding the metabolic pathways and genetic controls that regulate this process, it has been possible to tune the microbial cultures to produce a variety of PCCs, including PCCs that cannot be made using existing technologies. As the carbonates produced in this system are sourced from atmospheric CO2, not only does this represent a green solution to PCC production, but it also has the potential to be a previously unidentified mechanism of carbon-capture. In addition, the proposed technology is unique within current microbially-precipitated calcium carbonate technologies in that mined limestone is not required; nor is bacterial ureolysis utilized. Instead, the source of the carbonates in the PCCs produced using the proposed method is atmospheric CO2 with net carbon capture. By varying the chemical conditions for growth, it may be possible to generate PCCs with a variety of characteristics (particle size, particle shape, surface chemistry, and surface area) that are important in many industrial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Micron-scale precipitated calcium carbonates (PCCs) are used in variety of industries, from paper manufacturing (where PCCs provide a smooth surface and enhance brightness) to paint (where PCCs serve a pigment and rheology agent). Current PCCs are manufactured using an energy-intensive, industrial process that generates significant CO2, contributing up to 2% of total global CO2 emissions. This CO2 is primarily generated through the process of heating carbonate rocks up to 1,100°C (sintering) to generate PCCs, although mining and transportation also contribute to CO2 emissions. While product manufacturers are shifting production to materials obtained from sustainable sources, there are no alternate, green technologies for PCC production. Research in our lab has developed a novel method of creating PCCs from microbial growth, using a process that fixes atmospheric CO2 to generate the carbonates. This novel technology has a net carbon reduction of 1.6 tons of CO2 per ton of microbial PCCs produced, and allows us to generate microbial PCCs with a variety of characteristics (particle size, particle shape, surface chemistry, and surface area). These PCCs characteristics are important in industrial applications; however, our technology requires microbial growth and PCC extraction, resulting in a higher cost compared to traditional mining and sintering approaches. The I-Corps Teams program allowed us to explore several different customer segments to see if our product had value to industry. We interviewed over 120 potential customers across a range of industries, including thermoplastics manufacture, carbonate suppliers, paint manufacturers, cosmetics manufacturers, climbing and gymnastics chalk producers and users, agricultural users, and paper production. We discovered that our customers would be other businesses (B2B) and that many of these companies would be focused on reducing carbon emissions in their manufacturing processes. Our microbial PCCs are of interest to those industries interested in reducing emissions, such as paints, and the ability of our product to be produced on site with a consistency that is not possible with mined materials is particularly valuable; however, to have value in these markets would need to increase the scale of our microbial PCC production from the current 0.1 g/day to tons/days. Even with the myriad of benefits from our approach, due to the relatively thin margins of our business customers, our price point needs to be around $120/ton of PCC produced. Nonetheless, with very thin margins and the increasing use of carbon taxes to limit greenhouse gases, the need to find PCC alternatives is becoming an increasingly pressing problem for the minerals industry. Our findings suggest that a market exists for PCC production, providing that scalability is cost effective and that such emergent technologies can penetrate the large ($5.6 billion annually) commodities market.
